packages\/blade-icons\/1.0\/families\/ac.content:
#Installation

This package requires PHP 8.2 or later, and it supports Laravel 10 or later.

To get the latest version, simply require the project using Composer:

 1$ composer require bombenprodukt/blade-icons-academicons
 1$ composer require bombenprodukt/blade-icons-academicons

#Usage

The prefix for all icon families in this package is academicons. Please refer to the resources/svg directory for a list of available styles and icons.

#View Component

 1<x-academicons:{{ style }}-{{ icon }} />
 1<x-academicons:{{ style }}-{{ icon }} />

#Dynamic Component

 1<x-dynamic-component component="academicons:{{ $style }}-{{ $icon }}" />
 1<x-dynamic-component component="academicons:{{ $style }}-{{ $icon }}" />

document.title: Academicons
document.description: How to install and configure Academicons for Blade Icons.

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/configurati.content:
Arch comes with a configuration file that you can publish with the following command:

 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-config"
 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-config"

The published configuration file can be found at config/arch.php. You can review its contents via the following link: BombenProdukt/laravel-arch/config/arch.php. Upon first glance, you'll see that the configuration file solely contains a call to the Configuration class.

The minimalist design of the configuration file is intentional. All configuration values are set in the Configuration class, simplifying the management of these values. This setup also facilitates your review of the configuration values.

Moreover, this approach assists in maintaining backward compatibility for configuration values. For example, should we change the name of a configuration value, we can ensure backward compatibility by adding a new configuration value under the old name. This new value would then return the updated configuration value.

#Modification

Suppose you want to load stubs from a different location due to a unique directory structure. You can easily achieve this by modifying the stubPath value in the configuration file. This can be done by calling the stubPath method on the Configuration class. You can make these changes by modifying the config/arch.php file as follows:

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5use BombenProdukt\Arch\Configuration;


 6


 7return Configuration::make()


 8    ->stubPath(base_path('stubs'))


 9    ->toArray();
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5use BombenProdukt\Arch\Configuration;


 6


 7return Configuration::make()


 8    ->stubPath(base_path('stubs'))


 9    ->toArray();

That being said, we have taken the liberty to set all values to sensible defaults for you right out of the box. However, you are entirely free to modify these values to suit your specific needs.

#Swap

As you review the configuration file, you'll notice that almost all of the internals can be swapped out. This is achieved by using the Fully Qualified Class Name (FQCN) of the desired extension. For instance, if you wish to use a different reporter, you can set the FQCN of the reporter via the reporter method.

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5use BombenProdukt\Arch\Configuration;


 6


 7return Configuration::make()


 8    ->reporter(\BombenProdukt\Arch\Reporter\JsonReport::class)


 9    ->toArray();
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5use BombenProdukt\Arch\Configuration;


 6


 7return Configuration::make()


 8    ->reporter(\BombenProdukt\Arch\Reporter\JsonReport::class)


 9    ->toArray();

Arch, from the ground up, is designed to be extensible. This means that all internals are built with extensibility in mind, following the same conventions as a third-party package. There are no special rules for third-party packages, and we encourage you to create your own extensions to expand or replace the functionality of the library to customize it according to your needs.

#Extensions

As mentioned above, Arch is designed to be extensible. This means that you can easily extend the library with third-party packages or create your own extensions. We will explore this in greater detail in the Creating an Extension section.

#Gotchas

Do keep in mind that, in the case of the tokenizers array, the order of the tokenizers is significant. The tokenizers are executed in the order they are defined in the array. This can potentially result in unwanted side-effects, depending on how you want to tokenize the manifest. For instance, many aspects will be inferred from or rely on the defined models. Due to this, we strongly recommend defining the models tokenizer first. This ensures that the models are defined before any other tokenizers are executed.

document.title: Configuration
document.description: Learn how to configure Laravel Arch

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/core-concep.content:
The Environment class forms the core of the package. In itself, it possesses no functionality. Instead, it serves as a container for repositories that store the generators, statements, and tokenizers. This setup allows these elements to be accessible from anywhere in your application. The most common use-cases involve accessing the environment from an extension to register generators and tokenizers, or from a tokenizer to retrieve a statement based on its methods.

#Interface

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\GeneratorRepository;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\StatementRepository;


 9use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\TokenizerRepository;


 10


 11interface EnvironmentInterface


 12{


 13    public function generators(): GeneratorRepository;


 14


 15    public function statements(): StatementRepository;


 16


 17    public function tokenizers(): TokenizerRepository;


 18}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\GeneratorRepository;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\StatementRepository;


 9use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\TokenizerRepository;


 10


 11interface EnvironmentInterface


 12{


 13    public function generators(): GeneratorRepository;


 14


 15    public function statements(): StatementRepository;


 16


 17    public function tokenizers(): TokenizerRepository;


 18}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\Facade\Environment;


 8


 9final readonly class LaravelExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 10{


 11    public function register(array $configuration): void


 12    {


 13        foreach ($configuration['generators'] as $generator) {


 14            Environment::generators()->add($generator);


 15        }


 16


 17        foreach ($configuration['statements'] as $statement) {


 18            Environment::statements()->add($statement);


 19        }


 20


 21        foreach ($configuration['tokenizers'] as $tokenizer) {


 22            Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizer);


 23        }


 24    }


 25}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\Facade\Environment;


 8


 9final readonly class LaravelExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 10{


 11    public function register(array $configuration): void


 12    {


 13        foreach ($configuration['generators'] as $generator) {


 14            Environment::generators()->add($generator);


 15        }


 16


 17        foreach ($configuration['statements'] as $statement) {


 18            Environment::statements()->add($statement);


 19        }


 20


 21        foreach ($configuration['tokenizers'] as $tokenizer) {


 22            Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizer);


 23        }


 24    }


 25}

#References

  • Environment

document.title: Environment
document.description: Learn about the environment and how it works.

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/core-concep.content:
Extensions are a way to extend the package with your own generators and tokenizers. This is useful if you want to generate something that is not supported by the package out of the box.

#Configuration

In order to use extensions, you need to register them in the config/arch.php file. The extensions key is an array of fully qualified class names that implements the BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension\ExtensionInterface interface. You can review the contents of the config/arch.php file here.

#Interface

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface ExtensionInterface


 8{


 9    public function register(array $configuration): void;


 10}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface ExtensionInterface


 8{


 9    public function register(array $configuration): void;


 10}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract\ExtensionInterface;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Facade\Environment;


 9


 10final readonly class LaravelExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 11{


 12    public function register(array $configuration): void


 13    {


 14        foreach ($configuration['generators'] as $generator) {


 15            Environment::generators()->add($generator);


 16        }


 17


 18        foreach ($configuration['statements'] as $statement) {


 19            Environment::statements()->add($statement);


 20        }


 21


 22        foreach ($configuration['tokenizers'] as $tokenizerClassName => $tokenizerConfiguration) {


 23            if (\is_string($tokenizerClassName)) {


 24                Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizerClassName, $tokenizerConfiguration);


 25            } else {


 26                Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizerConfiguration);


 27            }


 28        }


 29    }


 30}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract\ExtensionInterface;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Facade\Environment;


 9


 10final readonly class LaravelExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 11{


 12    public function register(array $configuration): void


 13    {


 14        foreach ($configuration['generators'] as $generator) {


 15            Environment::generators()->add($generator);


 16        }


 17


 18        foreach ($configuration['statements'] as $statement) {


 19            Environment::statements()->add($statement);


 20        }


 21


 22        foreach ($configuration['tokenizers'] as $tokenizerClassName => $tokenizerConfiguration) {


 23            if (\is_string($tokenizerClassName)) {


 24                Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizerClassName, $tokenizerConfiguration);


 25            } else {


 26                Environment::tokenizers()->add($tokenizerConfiguration);


 27            }


 28        }


 29    }


 30}

#References

  • InertiaExtension
  • Laravel/NovaExtension
  • LaravelExtension
  • LivewireExtension

document.title: Extension
document.description: Learn how to extend the package with your own generators and tokenizers.

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/core-concep.content:
Generators are used to generate files from tokens which were created by tokenizers. For example, the JobGenerator can be used to generate a job file from a Job object. This file can then be written to disk and used by the application.

#Interface

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\GeneratorResult;


 8


 9interface GeneratorInterface


 10{


 11    public function generate(): void;


 12


 13    public function result(): GeneratorResult;


 14}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\GeneratorResult;


 8


 9interface GeneratorInterface


 10{


 11    public function generate(): void;


 12


 13    public function result(): GeneratorResult;


 14}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Generator\Laravel;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Facade\Tree;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Generator\AbstractGenerator;


 9


 10final class JobGenerator extends AbstractGenerator


 11{


 12    public function generate(): void


 13    {


 14        /**


 15         * @var \BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\Job


 16         */


 17        foreach (Tree::get('jobs') as $job) {


 18            $this->createFile(


 19                $job->name(),


 20                $this->renderClass($job, $job->shouldQueue() ? 'laravel/job/queued' : 'laravel/job/job', [


 21                    'class' => $job->name(),


 22                ]),


 23            );


 24        }


 25


 26        $this->persist();


 27    }


 28}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Generator\Laravel;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Facade\Tree;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Generator\AbstractGenerator;


 9


 10final class JobGenerator extends AbstractGenerator


 11{


 12    public function generate(): void


 13    {


 14        /**


 15         * @var \BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\Job


 16         */


 17        foreach (Tree::get('jobs') as $job) {


 18            $this->createFile(


 19                $job->name(),


 20                $this->renderClass($job, $job->shouldQueue() ? 'laravel/job/queued' : 'laravel/job/job', [


 21                    'class' => $job->name(),


 22                ]),


 23            );


 24        }


 25


 26        $this->persist();


 27    }


 28}

Reporters are used to transform the result of the build process into a summary. For example, the YamlReporter would transform the result into a YAML string, which would then be written to a file.

#Interface

 2

 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Reporter\Report;

 11{


 12    public function encode(GeneratorResult $result): Report;

 15}

 13


 14    public function decode(string $path): GeneratorResult;


 15}

#Example

 1<?php


 2

 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Reporter;


 6

 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\GeneratorResult;


 9use BombenProdukt\Arch\Path;


 10use Illuminate\Support\Facades\File;


 11use Symfony\Component\Serializer\Encoder\YamlEncoder;


 12use Symfony\Component\Serializer\Normalizer\ObjectNormalizer;


 13use Symfony\Component\Serializer\Serializer;


 14


 15final readonly class YamlReporter implements ReporterInterface


 16{


 17    private Serializer $serializer;


 18


 19    public function __construct()


 20    {


 21        $this->serializer = new Serializer([new ObjectNormalizer()], [new YamlEncoder()]);


 22    }


 23


 24    public function encode(GeneratorResult $result): Report


 25    {


 26        return new Report(


 27            path: Path::arch('report.yaml'),


 28            contents: $this->serializer->encode(


 29                $result->toArray(),


 30                'yaml',


 31                [YamlEncoder::YAML_INLINE => 32],


 32            ),


 33        );


 34    }


 35


 36    public function decode(string $path): GeneratorResult


 37    {


 38        return $this->serializer->deserialize(File::get($path), GeneratorResult::class, 'yaml');


 39    }


 40}

Statements can be thought of as child generators. They are used to generate code for a specific part of the application. For example, the RouteRedirectStatement would generate code for a route redirect.

#Interface

 2

 8{


 9    public function code(array $context = []): string;

 14


 15    public function traits(array $context = []): array;


 16}

 16}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Statement;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Renderer\FileRenderer;


 8use Illuminate\Support\Arr;


 9use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Redirect;


 10


 11final readonly class RouteRedirectStatement implements StatementInterface


 12{


 13    public function __construct(


 14        private string $name,


 15        private ?array $parameters = [],


 16    ) {


 17        //


 18    }


 19


 20    public function code(array $context = []): string


 21    {


 22        $hasParameters = \count($this->parameters) > 0;


 23


 24        return \sprintf(


 25            $hasParameters ? "return Redirect::route('%s', %s);" : "return Redirect::route('%s');",


 26            $this->name,


 27            $hasParameters ? Arr::propertiesToArray($this->parameters) : '',


 28        );


 29    }


 30


 31    public function test(array $context = []): string


 32    {


 33        return FileRenderer::render('redirect/test/route', [


 34            'name' => $this->name,


 35        ]);


 36    }


 37


 38    public function imports(array $context = []): array


 39    {


 40        return [


 41            Redirect::class,


 42        ];


 43    }


 44


 45    public function traits(array $context = []): array


 46    {


 47        return [];


 48    }


 49}

Tokenizers are used to transform tokens into normalized objects. For example, the ControllerTokenizer would transform a controller declaration into a Controller object, which would then be passed on to the ControllerGenerator class for further processing.

#Interface

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface TokenizerInterface


 8{


 9    public function tokenize(array $tokens): array;


 10}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface TokenizerInterface


 8{


 9    public function tokenize(array $tokens): array;


 10}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Tokenizer;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Model\Job;


 8


 9final readonly class JobTokenizer extends AbstractTokenizer


 10{


 11    public function tokenize(array $tokens): array


 12    {


 13        if (empty($tokens['jobs'])) {


 14            return [];


 15        }


 16


 17        $jobs = [];


 18


 19        foreach ($tokens['jobs'] as $key => $value) {


 20            $jobs[] = $this->populateMetadata(


 21                new Job(


 22                    name: \is_numeric($key) ? $value : $key,


 23                    shouldQueue: $value['shouldQueue'] ?? false,


 24                    shouldBeUnique: $value['shouldBeUnique'] ?? false,


 25                ),


 26                $value,


 27            );


 28        }


 29


 30        return [


 31            'jobs' => $jobs,


 32        ];


 33    }


 34}

Trees are used to store tokens which were created by tokenizers. For example, the ArrayTree can be used to store Controller objects. These objects can then be used by the application.

#Interface

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface TreeInterface


 8{


 9    public function add(string $type, ModelInterface $model, bool $replaceOnConflict): void;


 10


 11    public function get(string $type): array;


 12


 13    public function flush(): void;


 14


 15    public function merge(array $tokens, bool $replaceOnConflict): self;


 16}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract;


 6


 7interface TreeInterface


 8{


 9    public function add(string $type, ModelInterface $model, bool $replaceOnConflict): void;


 10


 11    public function get(string $type): array;


 12


 13    public function flush(): void;


 14


 15    public function merge(array $tokens, bool $replaceOnConflict): self;


 16}

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Tree;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract\ModelInterface;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Contract\TreeInterface;


 9use Illuminate\Support\Arr;


 10use Illuminate\Support\Traits\ForwardsCalls;


 11


 12final class ArrayTree implements TreeInterface


 13{


 14    use ForwardsCalls;


 15


 16    private array $tree = [];


 17


 18    public function add(string $type, ModelInterface $model, bool $replaceOnConflict = false): void


 19    {


 20        if (!Arr::has($this->tree, $type)) {


 21            Arr::set($this->tree, $type, []);


 22        }


 23


 24        foreach ($this->get($type) as $key => $value) {


 25            if ($value->name() === $model->name()) {


 26                if ($replaceOnConflict) {


 27                    Arr::forget($this->tree[$type], $key);


 28                }


 29            }


 30        }


 31


 32        $this->tree[$type][] = $model;


 33    }


 34


 35    public function get(string $type): array


 36    {


 37        return Arr::get($this->tree, $type, []);


 38    }


 39


 40    public function flush(): void


 41    {


 42        $this->tree = [];


 43    }


 44


 45    public function merge(array $tokens, bool $replaceOnConflict = false): self


 46    {


 47        foreach ($tokens as $type => $models) {


 48            foreach ($models as $modelType => $model) {


 49                // This handles nested definitions like nova.metrics to avoid keys like novaMetrics


 50                if (\is_array($model)) {


 51                    foreach ($model as $subModel) {


 52                        $this->add("{$type}.{$modelType}", $subModel, $replaceOnConflict);


 53                    }


 54                } else {


 55                    $this->add($type, $model, $replaceOnConflict);


 56                }


 57            }


 58        }


 59


 60        return $this;


 61    }


 62}

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/digging-dee.content:
Lets say you want to add a new generator to Arch. You can do this by creating a new extension. An extension is a class that implements the BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension\ExtensionInterface interface. The interface has one method register which is called when the extension is loaded. The register method receives the configuration for the extension.

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7interface ExtensionInterface


 8{


 9    public function register(array $configuration): void;


 10}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7interface ExtensionInterface


 8{


 9    public function register(array $configuration): void;


 10}

Given this interface, we can create a new extension that registers a new generator. The extension will register the CustomGenerator class as a generator. This will make it available to the arch:build command.

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use App\Arch\Generator\CustomGenerator;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\Facade\Environment;


 9use BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension\ExtensionInterface;


 10


 11final readonly class CustomExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 12{


 13    public function register(array $configuration): void


 14    {


 15        Environment::generators()->add(CustomGenerator::class);


 16    }


 17}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Arch\Extension;


 6


 7use App\Arch\Generator\CustomGenerator;


 8use BombenProdukt\Arch\Environment\Facade\Environment;


 9use BombenProdukt\Arch\Extension\ExtensionInterface;


 10


 11final readonly class CustomExtension implements ExtensionInterface


 12{


 13    public function register(array $configuration): void


 14    {


 15        Environment::generators()->add(CustomGenerator::class);


 16    }


 17}

The extension can be registered in the extensions array in the arch.php configuration file. The key is the fully qualified class name of the extension and the value is the configuration for the extension.

 1<?php


 2


 3return [


 4


 5    // ...


 6


 7    'extensions' => [


 8        App\Arch\Extension\CustomExtension::class => [],


 9    ],


 10


 11    // ...


 12


 13];
 1<?php


 2


 3return [


 4


 5    // ...


 6


 7    'extensions' => [


 8        App\Arch\Extension\CustomExtension::class => [],


 9    ],


 10


 11    // ...


 12


 13];

And that's it! Arch will now use the CustomGenerator class in the arch:build command. Happy coding!

Extensions are a great way to add new functionality to Arch. You can release your extension as a composer package and share it with the world, or keep it private and use it in your own projects by storing the extensions in the App\Arch\Extension directory.

document.title: Creating an Extension
document.description: Learn how to create an extension to add new functionality.

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/installatio.content:
This package requires PHP 8.2 or later, and it supports Laravel 10 or later.

#Composer

To get the latest version, simply require the project using Composer:

 1$ composer require --dev bombenprodukt/laravel-arch
 1$ composer require --dev bombenprodukt/laravel-arch

You can publish the configuration file by using:

 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-config"
 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-config"

You can publish the stubs by using:

 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-stubs"
 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-arch-stubs"

#Manifest

You can create the default manifest file by using:

 1$ php artisan arch:manifest
 1$ php artisan arch:manifest

This will create an manifest.yaml file in the .arch directory. You will need to customize this file to fit your application requirements.

#Build

Once you've filled out the manifest you can build your application by using:

 1$ php artisan arch:build
 1$ php artisan arch:build

This will generate the architecture for your application, including controllers, models, views, routes, tests, migrations and many more files.

document.title: Installation
document.description: Learn how to install Laravel Arch

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/the-basics\.content:
A manifest is a file that describes the structure of your application. It is used by the arch:build command to create the files and folders of your application. By default the manifest is written in YAML and is located at .arch/manifest.yaml within your project directory or repository.

#Example

Let's say you want to create a blog application. You will need a Post model and a Comment model. The Post model will have a hasMany relationship with the Comment model and the Comment model will have a belongsTo relationship with the Post model.

#Manifest

 1arch: 1.0.0


 2definitions:


 3  models:


 4    Post:


 5      columns:


 6        title: string


 7        content: longText


 8      relationships:


 9        hasMany: Comment


 10    Comment:


 11      columns:


 12        body: longText


 13      relationships:


 14        belongsTo: Post
 1arch: 1.0.0


 2definitions:


 3  models:


 4    Post:


 5      columns:


 6        title: string


 7        content: longText


 8      relationships:


 9        hasMany: Comment


 10    Comment:


 11      columns:


 12        body: longText


 13      relationships:


 14        belongsTo: Post

The above manifest will generate the files and folders needed to create the blog application. The arch:build command will create the following files and folders:

#Output

 1Created:


 2- app/Models/Comment.php


 3- app/Models/Post.php


 4- database/factories/CommentFactory.php


 5- database/factories/PostFactory.php


 6- database/migrations/2023_01_01_000000_create_posts_table.php


 7- database/migrations/2023_01_01_000001_create_comments_table.php


 8- database/seeders/CommentSeeder.php


 9- database/seeders/PostSeeder.php


 10- tests/Unit/Models/CommentTest.php


 11- tests/Unit/Models/PostTest.php
 1Created:


 2- app/Models/Comment.php


 3- app/Models/Post.php


 4- database/factories/CommentFactory.php


 5- database/factories/PostFactory.php


 6- database/migrations/2023_01_01_000000_create_posts_table.php


 7- database/migrations/2023_01_01_000001_create_comments_table.php


 8- database/seeders/CommentSeeder.php


 9- database/seeders/PostSeeder.php


 10- tests/Unit/Models/CommentTest.php


 11- tests/Unit/Models/PostTest.php

And that's it! You can now start working on your application. Happy coding!

You can change the location of the manifest that will be parsed by using the --manifest option of the arch:build command.

packages\/laravel-arch\/1.0\/the-basics\.content:
Arch comes with a few commands out of the box. You can see a list of all available commands by running php artisan arch: from the root of your project.

#Setup

The arch:setup command will create a new project in the current directory. This command will create the .arch directory with all the necessary files and directories. It will also create the manifest.yaml file, ready for you to edit.

 1$ php artisan arch:setup
 1$ php artisan arch:setup

#Build

The arch:build command will build your project. This command will parse the definitions in your manifest.yaml file. If you don't have a manifest.yaml file, it will prompt you to run the arch:setup command.

 1$ php artisan arch:build
 1$ php artisan arch:build

#Purge

The arch:purge command will purge your project. This command will delete the .arch directory and all the files and directories inside it. It will also delete the manifest.yaml file and all the files and directories that were generated as a result of it.

 1$ php artisan arch:purge
 1$ php artisan arch:purge

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/authent.content:
Laravel provides several different approaches to authenticate your application's incoming data. It is most common to use the auth middleware available on all incoming HTTP requests. However, this approach is not suitable for JSON-RPC requests. Instead, we will discuss other approaches to authentication as well.

#Request Authentication

If you want to authenticate your JSON-RPC requests, you should use a middleware and apply it to your server. We recommend to use an authentication middleware that is already available in Laravel. For example, you may use HTTP Basic Authentication or API Token Authentication.

#HTTP Basic Authentication

To authenticate your JSON-RPC requests using HTTP Basic Authentication, you should use the auth.basic middleware. You may assign the middleware to your server in the getMiddleware function:

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Server;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Http\Middleware\BootServer;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    public function getMiddleware(): array


 13    {


 14        return array_merge(


 15            ['auth.basic'],


 16            parent::getMiddleware(),


 17        );


 18    }


 19


 20    public function procedures(): array


 21    {


 22        return [


 23            \App\Http\Procedure\Subtract::class,


 24        ];


 25    }


 26}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Server;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Http\Middleware\BootServer;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    public function getMiddleware(): array


 13    {


 14        return array_merge(


 15            ['auth.basic'],


 16            parent::getMiddleware(),


 17        );


 18    }


 19


 20    public function procedures(): array


 21    {


 22        return [


 23            \App\Http\Procedure\Subtract::class,


 24        ];


 25    }


 26}

#API Token Authentication

To authenticate your JSON-RPC requests using API Token Authentication, you should use the auth:sanctum middleware. You may assign the middleware to your server in the getMiddleware function:

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Server;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Http\Middleware\BootServer;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    public function getMiddleware(): array


 13    {


 14        return array_merge(


 15            ['auth:sanctum'],


 16            parent::getMiddleware(),


 17        );


 18    }


 19


 20    public function procedures(): array


 21    {


 22        return [


 23            \App\Http\Procedure\Subtract::class,


 24        ];


 25    }


 26}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Server;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Http\Middleware\BootServer;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    public function getMiddleware(): array


 13    {


 14        return array_merge(


 15            ['auth:sanctum'],


 16            parent::getMiddleware(),


 17        );


 18    }


 19


 20    public function procedures(): array


 21    {


 22        return [


 23            \App\Http\Procedure\Subtract::class,


 24        ];


 25    }


 26}

#JSON-RPC Server Namespace

This value sets the namespace for the JsonRpc part of your application. This is used whenever a JSON-RPC server class is referenced within the application.

 1'namespace_server' => 'App\\Http\\Server',
 1'namespace_server' => 'App\\Http\\Server',

#JSON-RPC Servers

Here you may define a list of servers for your application. Each server is represented by its fully qualified class name.

This value determines where all the JSON-RPC server classes are stored. These classes are used to handle incoming JSON-RPC requests and are automatically registered with the application.

 1'servers' => [


 2    // \App\Http\Server\Server::class,

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/error-h.content:
Laravel provides several different approaches to handle errors in your application. We expose various exceptions as JSON-RPC errors. However, you may want to handle errors in your own way. In this chapter, we will discuss how to handle errors in your JSON-RPC API.

#Error Handling

If you want to handle errors in your JSON-RPC API, you should use a middleware and apply it to your server. We recommend to use an error handling middleware that is already available in Laravel. For example, you may use reporting errors or rendering errors.

#Creating Exceptions

If you want to create your own exceptions, you should extend the BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Exception\AbstractRequestException class. The class provides a constructor that accepts the following arguments:

  • int $errorCode - The error code of the exception.
  • string $errorMessage - The error message of the exception.
  • mixed $errorData - The error data of the exception.

Any exceptions that are not an instance of AbstractRequestException will be converted to an internal server error. The internal server error will have the error code -32603 and the error message Internal error. Exceptions that are an instance of AbstractRequestException will be converted to a JSON-RPC error response.

#Example

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Exception;


 6


 7final class MethodNotFoundException extends AbstractRequestException


 8{


 9    public function __construct(mixed $data = null)


 10    {


 11        parent::__construct(


 12            errorCode: -32601,


 13            errorMessage: 'Method not found',


 14            errorData: $data,


 15        );


 16    }


 17}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Exception;


 6


 7final class MethodNotFoundException extends AbstractRequestException


 8{


 9    public function __construct(mixed $data = null)


 10    {


 11        parent::__construct(


 12            errorCode: -32601,


 13            errorMessage: 'Method not found',


 14            errorData: $data,


 15        );


 16    }


 17}

#Reserved Error Codes

The JSON-RPC specification reserves the following error codes:

  • -32700 - Parse error (Invalid JSON was received by the server. An error occurred on the server while parsing the JSON text.)
  • -32600 - Invalid Request (The JSON sent is not a valid Request object.)
  • -32601 - Method not found (The method does not exist / is not available.)
  • -32602 - Invalid params (Invalid method parameter(s).)
  • -32603 - Internal error (Internal JSON-RPC error.)
  • -32000 to -32099 - Server error (Reserved for implementation-defined server-errors.)

The remainder of the space is available for application defined errors.

document.title: Error Handling
document.description: Learn how to handle errors in your JSON-RPC API.

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/install.content:
This package requires PHP 8.2 or later, and it supports Laravel 10 or later.

To get the latest version, simply require the project using Composer:

 1$ composer require bombenprodukt/laravel-json-rpc
 1$ composer require bombenprodukt/laravel-json-rpc

You can publish the configuration file by using:

 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-json-rpc-config"
 1$ php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-json-rpc-config"

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/procedu.content:
Procedures form the backbone of your JSON-RPC API, serving the critical role of handling requests. You have the liberty to create as many procedures as needed, yet each procedure can only be registered once per server per version. This implies that you can have a v1 server with a subtract procedure and a v2 server with a subtract procedure. However, it's not possible to have a v1 server featuring two subtract procedures unless they represent different versions.

#Creating A Procedure With Positional Parameters (Full Example)

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9


 10final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 11{


 12    public function handle(RequestObject $requestObject): int


 13    {


 14        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 15    }


 16


 17    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default version.


 18    public function getVersion(): string


 19    {


 20        return '1.0.0';


 21    }


 22}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9


 10final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 11{


 12    public function handle(RequestObject $requestObject): int


 13    {


 14        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 15    }


 16


 17    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default version.


 18    public function getVersion(): string


 19    {


 20        return '1.0.0';


 21    }


 22}

#Creating A Procedure With Positional Parameters (Slim Example)

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9


 10final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 11{


 12    public function handle(RequestObject $requestObject): int


 13    {


 14        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 15    }


 16}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9


 10final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 11{


 12    public function handle(RequestObject $requestObject): int


 13    {


 14        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 15    }


 16}

#Creating A Procedure With Named Parameters (Full Example)

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 8


 9final class SubtractWithBinding extends AbstractProcedure


 10{


 11    public function handle(string $minuend, string $subtrahend): int


 12    {


 13        return $minuend - $subtrahend;


 14    }


 15


 16    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default version.


 17    public function getVersion(): string


 18    {


 19        return '1.0.0';


 20    }


 21}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 8


 9final class SubtractWithBinding extends AbstractProcedure


 10{


 11    public function handle(string $minuend, string $subtrahend): int


 12    {


 13        return $minuend - $subtrahend;


 14    }


 15


 16    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default version.


 17    public function getVersion(): string


 18    {


 19        return '1.0.0';


 20    }


 21}

#Creating A Procedure With Named Parameters (Slim Example)

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 8


 9final class SubtractWithBinding extends AbstractProcedure


 10{


 11    public function handle(string $minuend, string $subtrahend): int


 12    {


 13        return $minuend - $subtrahend;


 14    }


 15}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 8


 9final class SubtractWithBinding extends AbstractProcedure


 10{


 11    public function handle(string $minuend, string $subtrahend): int


 12    {


 13        return $minuend - $subtrahend;


 14    }


 15}

#Versions

If you wish to request a specific version of a procedure, you have the option to do so by including the X-JSON-RPC-Procedure-Version header in your request. In cases where this header is absent, the request handler will default to utilizing the standard procedure. This default procedure can be identified by returning true from the isDefault method linked with the procedure.

Such an approach grants you the flexibility of maintaining a procedure with multiple versions for backwards compatibility, while also possessing a default procedure which can be called upon without necessitating the X-JSON-RPC-Procedure-Version header. Additionally, this strategy facilitates specifying the default version of a procedure based on certain business logic, instead of relying solely on a simple boolean flag.

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/request.content:
Once you have your JSON-RPC API up and running, you can start sending requests to it. This page will show you how to send requests to your JSON-RPC API. It will also show you how to handle the responses.

#JSON-RPC Client

#Usage

You can create a client by using the BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Client\Client class.

 1$client = Client::make('https://jsonrpc.example.com');
 1$client = Client::make('https://jsonrpc.example.com');

Once you have created a client, you can start adding requests to it.

 1$client->add(RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [42, 23]));
 1$client->add(RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [42, 23]));

If you want to add multiple requests at once, you can use the addMany method.

 1$client->addMany([


 2    RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [42, 23]),


 3    RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [23, 42])


 4]);
 1$client->addMany([


 2    RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [42, 23]),


 3    RequestObject::make(Str::uuid(), 'subtract', [23, 42])


 4]);

After you have added all the requests you want to send, you can send them by using the request method.

 1$responseObjects = $client->request();
 1$responseObjects = $client->request();

Note that the request method will return an array of BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Client\ResponseObject objects. Each response object will contain the response for the request that was sent.

#Request Object Helpers

The BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject class provides several helper methods that aid in the creation of request objects. Two of these methods are asRequest and asNotification.

The asRequest method crafts a request object, which expects a response from the server. On the other hand, the asNotification method generates a request object that does not anticipate a response from the server.

#Request

The asRequest method accepts three parameters. The first parameter is the method name. The second parameter is the parameters that should be sent to the server. The third parameter is the ID of the request object and is optional.

 1$client->add(RequestObject::asRequest('subtract', [42, 23]));
 1$client->add(RequestObject::asRequest('subtract', [42, 23]));
 1$client->add(RequestObject::asRequest('subtract', [42, 23], 'id'));
 1$client->add(RequestObject::asRequest('subtract', [42, 23], 'id'));

#Notification

The asNotification method accepts two parameters. The first parameter is the method name. The second parameter is the parameters that should be sent to the server.

 1$client->add(RequestObject::asNotification('update', [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]));
 1$client->add(RequestObject::asNotification('update', [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]));

#JSON-RPC Call Examples

#Syntax

 1--> Data Sent To Server


 2<-- Data Sent To Client
 1--> Data Sent To Server


 2<-- Data Sent To Client

#With Positional Parameters

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [42, 23], "id": 1}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 1}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [42, 23], "id": 1}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 1}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [23, 42], "id": 2}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": -19, "id": 2}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [23, 42], "id": 2}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": -19, "id": 2}

#With Named Parameters

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": {"subtrahend": 23, "minuend": 42}, "id": 3}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 3}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": {"subtrahend": 23, "minuend": 42}, "id": 3}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 3}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": {"minuend": 42, "subtrahend": 23}, "id": 4}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 4}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": {"minuend": 42, "subtrahend": 23}, "id": 4}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": 4}

#A Notification

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "update", "params": [1,2,3,4,5]}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "update", "params": [1,2,3,4,5]}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar"}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar"}

#Of Non Existent Method

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar", "id": "1"}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32601, "message": "Method not found"}, "id": "1"}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar", "id": "1"}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32601, "message": "Method not found"}, "id": "1"}

#With Invalid Json

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar, "params": "bar", "baz]


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32700, "message": "Parse error"}, "id": null}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foobar, "params": "bar", "baz]


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32700, "message": "Parse error"}, "id": null}

#With Invalid Request Object

 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": 1, "params": "bar"}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}
 1--> {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": 1, "params": "bar"}


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}

#Batch Invalid Json

 1--> [


 2    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "sum", "params": [1,2,4], "id": "1"},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method"


 4]


 5<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32700, "message": "Parse error"}, "id": null}
 1--> [


 2    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "sum", "params": [1,2,4], "id": "1"},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method"


 4]


 5<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32700, "message": "Parse error"}, "id": null}

#With An Empty Array

 1--> []


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}
 1--> []


 2<-- {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}

#With An Invalid Batch But Not Empty

 1--> [1]


 2<-- [


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}


 4]
 1--> [1]


 2<-- [


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}


 4]

#With Invalid Batch

 1--> [1,2,3]


 2<-- [


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 4    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 5    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}


 6]
 1--> [1,2,3]


 2<-- [


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 4    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 5    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null}


 6]

#Batch

 1--> [


 2{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "sum", "params": [1,2,4], "id": "1"},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_hello", "params": [7]},


 4    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [42,23], "id": "2"},


 5    {"foo": "boo"},


 6    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foo.get", "params": {"name": "myself"}, "id": "5"},


 7    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "get_data", "id": "9"}


 8]


 9<-- [


 10    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 7, "id": "1"},


 11    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": "2"},


 12    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 13    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32601, "message": "Method not found"}, "id": "5"},


 14    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": ["hello", 5], "id": "9"}


 15]
 1--> [


 2{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "sum", "params": [1,2,4], "id": "1"},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_hello", "params": [7]},


 4    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "subtract", "params": [42,23], "id": "2"},


 5    {"foo": "boo"},


 6    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "foo.get", "params": {"name": "myself"}, "id": "5"},


 7    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "get_data", "id": "9"}


 8]


 9<-- [


 10    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 7, "id": "1"},


 11    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": 19, "id": "2"},


 12    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32600, "message": "Invalid Request"}, "id": null},


 13    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "error": {"code": -32601, "message": "Method not found"}, "id": "5"},


 14    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "result": ["hello", 5], "id": "9"}


 15]

#Batch All Notifications

 1--> [


 2    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_sum", "params": [1,2,4]},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_hello", "params": [7]}


 4]


 5<-- //Nothing is returned for all notification batches
 1--> [


 2    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_sum", "params": [1,2,4]},


 3    {"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "notify_hello", "params": [7]}


 4]


 5<-- //Nothing is returned for all notification batches

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/servers.content:
Servers act as the entry point for your JSON-RPC API. They shoulder the responsibility of registering procedures and managing requests. While you have the freedom to create as many servers as you desire, a particular procedure can only be registered once per server per version. For instance, you could have a v1 server with a subtract procedure and a v2 server with a subtract procedure. However, it is not permissible to have a v1 server with two subtract procedures unless these procedures belong to distinct versions.

#Creating a Server (Full Example)

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Server;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Http\Middleware\BootServer;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default route path.


 13    public function getRoutePath(): string


 14    {


 15        return '/';


 16    }


 17


 18    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default route name.


 19    public function getRouteName(): string


 20    {


 21        return 'json-rpc.v1';


 22    }


 23


 24    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default version.


 25    public function getVersion(): string


 26    {


 27        return '1.0.0';


 28    }


 29


 30    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default middleware.


 31    public function getMiddleware(): array


 32    {


 33        return [


 34            BootServer::class,


 35        ];


 36    }


 37


 38    public function procedures(): array


 39    {


 40        return [


 41            \App\Http\Procedure\Subtract::class,


 42        ];


 43    }


 44}

 6

 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Server\AbstractServer;


 9


 10final class Server extends AbstractServer


 11{


 12    // This can be omitted if you want to use the default route path.


 13    public function getRoutePath(): string


 14    {


 15        return '/';


 16    }

 19    public function getRouteName(): string


 20    {

 39    {

#Registering a Server

 1Route::jsonRpc(\App\Http\Server\Server::class);
 1Route::jsonRpc(\App\Http\Server\Server::class);

#Versions

If you wish to request a specific version of a server, you have the option to do so by including the X-JSON-RPC-Server-Version header in your request. In cases where this header is absent, the request handler will default to utilizing the standard server. This default server can be identified by returning true from the isDefault method linked with the server.

Such an approach grants you the flexibility of maintaining a server with multiple versions for backwards compatibility, while also possessing a default server which can be called upon without necessitating the X-JSON-RPC-Server-Version header. Additionally, this strategy facilitates specifying the default version of a server based on certain business logic, instead of relying solely on a simple boolean flag.

packages\/laravel-json-rpc\/1.0\/validat.content:
Laravel provides several different approaches to validate your application's incoming data. It is most common to use the validate method available on all incoming HTTP requests. However, we will discuss other approaches to validation as well.

#Request Validation

If you want to validate your JSON-RPC requests, you can use the validate method available on all incoming HTTP requests. This method accepts an array of validation rules and will automatically return a JSON response with a 422 status code if the validation rules fail. If the validation rules pass, your code will keep executing normally.

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9use Illuminate\Http\Request;


 10


 11final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 12{


 13    public function handle(Request $request, RequestObject $requestObject): int


 14    {


 15        $validated = $request->validate([


 16            'title' => 'required|unique:posts|max:255',


 17            'body' => 'required',


 18        ]);


 19


 20        // The blog post is valid...


 21


 22        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 23    }


 24}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 9use Illuminate\Http\Request;


 10


 11final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 12{


 13    public function handle(Request $request, RequestObject $requestObject): int


 14    {


 15        $validated = $request->validate([


 16            'title' => 'required|unique:posts|max:255',


 17            'body' => 'required',


 18        ]);


 19


 20        // The blog post is valid...


 21


 22        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 23    }


 24}

#Form Request Validation

We recommend using Form Request Validation when validating your JSON-RPC requests. This approach keeps your procedure clean and allows you to reuse your validation rules in other parts of your application. You also get access to the authorize method, which allows you to authorize the incoming request.

 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use App\Http\Requests\ExampleRequest;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 9use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 10use Illuminate\Http\Request;


 11


 12final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 13{


 14    public function handle(ExampleRequest $request, RequestObject $requestObject): int


 15    {


 16        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 17    }


 18}
 1<?php


 2


 3declare(strict_types=1);


 4


 5namespace App\Http\Procedure;


 6


 7use App\Http\Requests\ExampleRequest;


 8use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Model\RequestObject;


 9use BombenProdukt\JsonRpc\Procedure\AbstractProcedure;


 10use Illuminate\Http\Request;


 11


 12final class Subtract extends AbstractProcedure


 13{


 14    public function handle(ExampleRequest $request, RequestObject $requestObject): int


 15    {


 16        return $requestObject->getParams()[0] - $requestObject->getParams()[1];


 17    }


 18}

packages\/laravel-lighty\/1.0\/annotatio.content:
Ranges are utilized for applying annotations across a series of lines. They possess a variety of applications. The examples provided below are all valid, and they will demonstrate the highlight annotation for illustrative purposes.

#Current

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation to the current line.

 1highlight
 1highlight

#Start

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation starting from the current line. This has to be used in conjunction with the end annotation.

 1highlight:start
 1highlight:start

#End

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation up to the current line. This has to be used in conjunction with the start annotation.

 1highlight:end
 1highlight:end

#Following

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation to the following lines.

 1highlight:10
 1highlight:10

#Following (Range)

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation starting from the next line, and highlight 10 lines total.

 1highlight:1,10
 1highlight:1,10

#Preceding

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation to the preceding lines.

 1highlight:-10
 1highlight:-10

#Preceding (Range)

This will apply the effects of the highlight annotation starting from the previous line, and highlight 10 lines total.

 1highlight:-1,10
 1highlight:-1,10

document.title: Ranges
document.description: Ranges are utilized for applying annotations across a series of lines.

packages\/laravel-lighty\/1.0\/configura.content:
You may publish the configuration file using the following command:

 1php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-lighty-config"
 1php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-lighty-config"

#Storage Path

The storage_path option defines the path where Lighty will store extensions, grammars and themes. This path should be relative to the root of your project.

 1'storage_path' => storage_path('lighty'),
 1'storage_path' => storage_path('lighty'),

#Grammars

The grammars option defines the grammars that Lighty should synchronize. Each grammar should be a project from the Visual Studio Marketplace.

 1'grammars' => [],
 1'grammars' => [],

#Themes

The themes option defines the themes that Lighty should synchronize. Each theme should be a project from the Visual Studio Marketplace.

 1'themes' => [],
 1'themes' => [],

#Default Language

The language option defines the default language that Lighty should use. This language will be used if no language is specified in the annotation.

 1'language' => 'php',
 1'language' => 'php',

#Default Theme

The theme option defines the default theme that Lighty should use. This theme will be used if no theme is specified in the annotation.

 1'theme' => 'nord',
 1'theme' => 'nord',

#Regular Expression

The regexp option defines the regular expression that Lighty should use to parse your code. The default expression is [lighty\s(.+?)]. You may need to change this value if you are using a different syntax.

 1'regexp' => '/\[lighty\s(.+?)\]/',
 1'regexp' => '/\[lighty\s(.+?)\]/',

#Annotations

The annotations option defines the annotations that Lighty should parse. Each annotation should be a class that implements the AnnotationInterface. You may add your own annotations to this array if you wish.

 1'annotations' => [


 2    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\AddAnnotation::class,


 3    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\AutolinkAnnotation::class,


 4    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\CollapseAnnotation::class,


 5    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\DeleteAnnotation::class,


 6    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\FocusAnnotation::class,


 7    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HighlightAnnotation::class,


 8    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HtmlClassAnnotation::class,


 9    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HtmlIdAnnotation::class,


 10    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\LineNumberAnnotation::class,


 11],
 1'annotations' => [


 2    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\AddAnnotation::class,


 3    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\AutolinkAnnotation::class,


 4    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\CollapseAnnotation::class,


 5    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\DeleteAnnotation::class,


 6    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\FocusAnnotation::class,


 7    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HighlightAnnotation::class,


 8    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HtmlClassAnnotation::class,


 9    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\HtmlIdAnnotation::class,


 10    BombenProdukt\Lighty\Annotation\LineNumberAnnotation::class,


 11],

#Line Numbers

The showLineNumbers option defines whether Lighty should show line numbers. You may disable this if you wish to do so.

 1'showLineNumbers' => true,
 1'showLineNumbers' => true,

#Diff Indicators

The showDiffIndicators option defines whether Lighty should show diff indicators. This will show a + or - next to each line to indicate whether it has been added or removed. You may disable this if you wish to do so.

 1'showDiffIndicators' => true,
 1'showDiffIndicators' => true,

#Diff Indicators In Place Of Line Numbers

The showDiffIndicatorsInPlaceOfLineNumbers option defines whether Lighty should show diff indicators in place of line numbers. This will show a + or - next to each line to indicate whether it has been added or removed. You may disable this if you wish to do so.

 1'showDiffIndicatorsInPlaceOfLineNumbers' => true,
 1'showDiffIndicatorsInPlaceOfLineNumbers' => true,

packages\/laravel-lighty\/1.0\/extension.content:
Lighty offers a CommonMark extension that allows you to use annotations in your markdown files. To use this extension, you must add it to your CommonMark Environment.

#Local Rendering

The LocalRenderer will render the code on your server. This is the recommended renderer if you are working with code that you don't want to send to a third-party API. It requires you to have Shiki and linkify-urls on your server.

 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\FencedCodeRenderer;


 2use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\LocalRenderer;


 3use League\CommonMark\Extension\CommonMark\Node\Block\FencedCode;


 4use League\CommonMark\Environment\Environment;


 5use League\CommonMark\MarkdownConverter;


 6


 7$environment = new Environment();


 8$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new LocalRenderer()));


 9


 10$converter = new MarkdownConverter($environment);


 11echo $converter->convert('**Hello World!**');
 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\FencedCodeRenderer;


 2use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\LocalRenderer;


 3use League\CommonMark\Extension\CommonMark\Node\Block\FencedCode;


 4use League\CommonMark\Environment\Environment;


 5use League\CommonMark\MarkdownConverter;


 6


 7$environment = new Environment();


 8$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new LocalRenderer()));


 9


 10$converter = new MarkdownConverter($environment);


 11echo $converter->convert('**Hello World!**');

#Remote Rendering

The RemoteRenderer will render the code using the Lighty API. This renderer will send your code to the API and return the rendered HTML. This will require you to have an API token. You can get an API token by signing up on uselighty.com.

 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\FencedCodeRenderer;


 2use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\RemoteRenderer;


 3use League\CommonMark\Extension\CommonMark\Node\Block\FencedCode;


 4use League\CommonMark\Environment\Environment;


 5use League\CommonMark\MarkdownConverter;


 6


 7$environment = new Environment();


 8$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new RemoteRenderer('YOUR_API_TOKEN')));


 9


 10$converter = new MarkdownConverter($environment);


 11echo $converter->convert('**Hello World!**');
 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\FencedCodeRenderer;


 2use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\RemoteRenderer;


 3use League\CommonMark\Extension\CommonMark\Node\Block\FencedCode;


 4use League\CommonMark\Environment\Environment;


 5use League\CommonMark\MarkdownConverter;


 6


 7$environment = new Environment();


 8$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new RemoteRenderer('YOUR_API_TOKEN')));


 9


 10$converter = new MarkdownConverter($environment);


 11echo $converter->convert('**Hello World!**');

#Caching

The CacheRenderer will cache the rendered HTML. This is useful when you are rendering a lot of code blocks, like for example when you are rendering a blog post. This renderer will prevent the same code block from being rendered multiple times.

 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\CacheRenderer;


 2


 3$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new CacheRenderer(new RemoteRenderer('YOUR_API_TOKEN'))));
 1use BombenProdukt\Lighty\CommonMark\CacheRenderer;


 2


 3$environment->addRenderer(FencedCode::class, new FencedCodeRenderer(new CacheRenderer(new RemoteRenderer('YOUR_API_TOKEN'))));

packages\/laravel-lighty\/1.0\/installat.content:
To get the latest version, simply require the project using Composer:

 1composer require bombenprodukt/laravel-lighty
 1composer require bombenprodukt/laravel-lighty

You can publish the configuration file by using:

 1php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-lighty-config"
 1php artisan vendor:publish --tag="laravel-lighty-config"

You'll also need to install Shiki and linkify-urls on your server, which you can do by using:

 1npm install shiki linkify-urls
 1npm install shiki linkify-urls

Finally you'll need to include the Lighty CSS file, which you can do by using:

 1@import "../../vendor/bombenprodukt/laravel-lighty/resources/css/lighty.css";
 1@import "../../vendor/bombenprodukt/laravel-lighty/resources/css/lighty.css";

That's it! You're ready to go. If you have any questions, please feel free to open a discussion on GitHub.

packages\/laravel-lighty\/1.0\/rest-api..content:
Lighty offers a REST API that allows you to render code blocks remotely. You can get an API token by signing up on uselighty.com.

#Gotchas

#Updating Resources

In order to ensure that previously created documents are always rendered with the same contents, language and theme, you cannot update any of those resources. If you need to update a document, you will need to create a new one. The same applies to languages and themes. If you need to update a language or theme, you will need to create a new one.

#Deleting Resources

We do allow you to delete documents, languages and themes. However, deleting languages or themes will not affect any documents that are using them. If you delete a language or theme, the documents that are using them will continue to use them. If you want to change the language or theme of a document, you will need to create a new one.

#Endpoints

#List Documents

 1curl --request GET \


 2    --url https://uselighty.com/api/teams/{team}/documents \


 3    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \


 4    --header 'Accept: application/json' \


 5    --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN'
 1curl --request GET \


 2    --url https://uselighty.com/api/teams/{team}/documents \


 3    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \


 4    --header 'Accept: application/json' \


 5    --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN'

#Create Document

  • The body field is required and must be a base64 string.
  • The language field is optional and must be a string.
  • The theme field is optional and must be a string.
 1curl --request POST \


 2    --url https://uselighty.com/api/teams/{team}/documents \


 3    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \


 4    --header 'Accept: application/json' \


 5    --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN' \


 6    --data '{


 7        "body": "...",


 8	    "language": "...",


 9	    "theme": "..."


 10    }'
 1curl --request POST \


 2    --url https://uselighty.com/api/teams/{team}/documents \


 3    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \


 4    --header 'Accept: application/json' \


 5    --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN' \


 6    --data '{


 7        "body": "...",

 9	    "theme": "..."


 10    }'

 3    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \


 4    --header 'Accept: application/json' \


 5    --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN'
